title: Evacuees on edge as Thai-Cambodia conflict escalates | The World | ABC NEWS
description: Shelling at the Thai-Cambodia border has continued into a second day, spreading further into civilian areas and forcing thousands to flee their homes. Cambodia says nine of its civilians have been killed, while Thailand has reported the deaths of four soldiers. As Rebecca Johnston reports, some living along the border are choosing to stay behind to defend their villages, risking their safety in a conflict that is escalating by the day. title: Imran Khan's sister tells ABC former Pakistan PM suffering mentally in jail | The World | ABC News
description: The family of jailed former Pakistani prime minister and cricket great Imran Khan say he is struggling with isolation and psychological strain. One of his sisters, Uzma, has been allowed to see him in jail after weeks of being blocked from having visitors. Khan was convicted for corruption in separate cases, including selling state gifts and accepting land as part of a bribe. His other sister, Aleem Khan, spoke with Girish Sawlani from 'The World' about her brother's condition. title: Zelenskyy accused of placating Trump with election pledge | ABC NEWS
description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy is facing criticism over his promise to hold elections within three months if the US and allies could provide security guarantees. Critics of the move are accusing the Ukrainian leader of trying to appease US President Donald Trump.  The country’s opposition MP Oleksiy Goncharenko says Zelenskyy’s pledge is part of his ‘game’ with the White House and he sees benefits in hosting a quick election as the best-prepared politician in Ukraine. title: US could ask Australian visitors for five years of social media history | ABC NEWS
description: Australian visitors to the United States could be required to provide a five-year record of their social media activity for entry into the country, under a new proposal from the Trump administration.  The proposed change would affect travellers from 42 visa-exempt countries under the ESTA system such as the UK, New Zealand, France, Japan and Australia. Immigration lawyer Melissa Vincenty says the proposed scheme is a ‘digging expedition’ to expose people who have anti-American ideology and may pose a threat to the American people. title: Some kids still have access to social media despite ban | ABC NEWS
description: Australia’s world-first under-16s social media ban hasn’t been a smooth launch with some children retaining access to their social accounts. Political reporter Isabella Tolhurst explains how the first 24-hours of the ban unfolded. title: Why Anika Wells’ travel costs don’t fly with taxpayers | ABC News Daily podcast
description: Imagine being able to claim thousands and thousands of dollars in expenses so your family can join you on work trips, or to fly business class to New York, or for private drivers to take you to the biggest sporting events.    Well, Minister Anika Wells is under intense pressure to justify her use of taxpayer funds, even if it’s all within the rules.   Today, the chief political correspondent at The Conversation, Michelle Grattan on why the perks for politicians are a honey pot and a trap.    Featured:    Michelle Grattan, chief political correspondent at The Conversation and a professorial fellow at the University of Canberra

title: Greg Lynn has conviction for the murder of Carol Clay set aside and a new trial ordered | ABC NEWS
description: Former Jetstar pilot Greg Lynn has had his conviction for the murder of Carol Clay set aside and a new trial has been ordered. A Supreme Court jury last year found Lynn guilty of murdering retiree Ms Clay at a campsite they shared in Victoria's High Country in March 2020, but acquitted him of murdering her companion, Russell Hill. Lynn has always maintained his innocence, saying the pair died tragic, accidental deaths following a dispute involving a knife and one of his guns. Greg Lynn's appeal was heard by a panel of three judges - Court of Appeal President, Karin Emerton, Justice Phillip Priest and Justice Peter Kidd. title: US seizes oil tanker off Venezuelan coast | ABC NEWS
description: US authorities have seized an oil tanker off the coast of Venezuela, according to US President Donald Trump.  US Attorney General Pam Bondi says the FBI, Homeland Security and the US Coast Guard and the Department of War were involved in the seizure of a vessel allegedly used to transport sanctioned oil from Venezuela to Iran.  The development is the latest in a saga of simmering tensions between the Washington and Caracas over US strikes on alleged drug boats which killed at least 80 people. title: Court case seeks to force betting firms to return money stolen by problem gamblers | ABC NEWS
description: A landmark case has been filed in the Federal Court against three of Australia’s biggest online betting agencies. Former financial planner Gavin Fineff is suing Sportsbet, Tabcorp and Entain, seeking to recover millions of dollars he stole from clients and gambled away with the companies. Fineff, who is in prison, is also suing two former VIP customer managers, alleging they helped facilitate his reckless gambling while ignoring "red flag" behaviours. title: Australian scientist and Venezuelan activist receive Nobel prizes | ABC NEWS
description: Australian professor Richard Robson has officially received the Nobel Prize for Chemistry alongside two other scientists for their development of metal organic frameworks.  Their study, which was sparked during professor Robson's chemistry lesson at Melbouurne University in 1974, has enabled technology to harvest water from desert air and capture carbon dioxide.  Meanwhile, Venezuelan opposition leader María Corina Machado’s daughter Ana Corina Sosa has accepted the Nobel peace prize on her mother’s behalf in Oslo. The Venezuelan activist could not make it to the award presentation ceremony as she was in hiding and banned from travelling overseas.  The Nobel Peace Prize laureate has been criticised over her vocal support for US President Donald Trump and US strikes on alleged drug-smuggling boats in the Caribbean. title: Sheriffs, crown solicitors and lawyers join SA prison strike | ABC NEWS
description: South Australia's court system has ground to a halt after sheriffs, crown solicitors and lawyers joined prison officers in a strike. The state's prison system has been in lockdown for 72 hours, which will continue for at least another day. The union wants to see a 20 per cent pay rise over 18 months which the South Australian government says is not sustainable. title: US Federal Reserve makes third consecutive rate cut on split decision | ABC NEWS
description: The US Federal Reserve has cut interest rates in a split 9-3 decision, with the official rate now at 3.5%-3.75%. Radio National’s Peter Martin says it's the most divided decision by the US central bank in six years, and divided decisions are more common when the way forward is unclear. title: Toyah's Murder: Comparing the two trials of Rajwinder Singh | ABC NEWS
description: It's been hard to keep secret, but the trial you've been following on this podcast was not the first one for Rajwinder Singh — it was a retrial, after an earlier hung jury.   In this episode, Chris Testa explains to Stephen Stockwell how the trials differed and legal strategies changed, including a change in focus on Toyah's boyfriend, Marco Heidenreich.   If you have any questions you'd like Chris and Stocky to answer in future episodes, please email thecaseof@abc.net.au (mailto:thecaseof@abc.net.au) .   The Case Of is the follow-up to the hit podcast Mushroom Case Daily, and all episodes of that show will remain available in the back catalogue of The Case Of.
